page.title: 03FARMING IN TURTON
page.content: The principal land owner is the North West Water Board, but the land is rented to local farmers. A vetinary surgeon owns 70 acres of farmland, and large areas of residential land. A herd of 16 wild ponies roams on this farmland. A consortium of Manchester businessmen own 23 acres which is used for hay production. The local farmers concentrate on sheep and hill cattle, the sheep being Gimmer Shearling, the cattle Herefords. Much of the land is too poor for farming and is left as moorland. Two farmers operate as milkmen, buying 8,000 pints of milk each from Dairy Crest of Bamber Bridge. One farmers owns 500 hens and sells eggs, as well as milk and cream.
